Award.AwardTitle: UNS: A Versatile Optofluidic Platform for Multiplexed Detection of Cardiac Biomarkers in Blood

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Wei, Jianjun
Proposal: 1511194

The goal is to develop a novel platform that incorporates an optical transmission sensing scheme with an automated size-dependent sample delivery system in a single nanoscale unit. The results will lead to a chip-based, point-of-care (POC) technology for early diagnosis of cardiovascular disease (CVD).


This project will investigate a plasmonic nano-optofluidic (PNOF) platform to demonstrate its utility and versatility of in-situ cell separation and delivery of small molecules to the sensing area, and discriminative, sensitive quantitation of protein biomarkers in whole blood. Unique metal film structures will be used as plasmonic waveguides to tune the spectrum that enables ultrasensitive and high signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio detection. The array will be utilized to integrate with a microfluidic network to realize in-situ separation of cells and size-exclusive delivery biomarkers. The researchers will then adopt the immunoassay format and demonstrate delivery and discrimination of selected biomarkers in human blood.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this project is to investigate a plasmonic nano-optofluidic (PNOF) platform to realize and demonstrate its versatility of in-situ cell separation and delivery of smaller molecules to sensing area, and discriminative, sensitive quantitation of the CVD protein biomarkers. To this end, we have completed this project by fulfilling the specific goals listed in the project description. Here we summarize as follows:

Intellectual Merit: We developed a new biosensor technology, PNOF platform. Through this project, we optimized a nanoplasmonic structure by the analysis of surface plasmon generation (SPG) efficiency and computational modeling and validated in experimental testing. The device is readily to be integrated with microfluidic channels and has been demonstrated for protein delivery to sensing area for detection. The semi-analytical SPG model became a general tool for design and analyze the similar gap-based plasmonic device. The innovation of the device was initially filed a provisional patent and these outcomes led to a non-provisional patent (pending). The research expanded our knowledge on the chip-based nanostructured localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) in design and application for sensing, not only for heart disease biomarker (e.g. troponin) and other biomarkers (such as diabetic biomarkers). The research results have been disseminated in different pathways, including eight research articles, one book chapters, a few national and regional conference presentations (Gordon Research Conference, Boston Nano Conference, et c.), and invited seminars.

broader Impacts: This project greatly stimulated the research on lab-on-chip based point-of-care device at JSNN and the Gateway Research Park in Greensboro. We obtained additional two grant related to this research topic including an NSF I-Corps award and a funding from North Carolina Biotechnology Center (NCBC) through the Tech Enhancement Program (TEG) focusing on developing low-cost, high throughput fabrication of the optimized device. Based on the advances of the project, the I-Corps team founded a start-up company, 3i-Nanotech, Inc. at the Research Park. Recently an NSF SBIR Phase I was awarded to the company to further advance the technology for commercialization. During the entire life of the award, a total five graduate students (including two female students and one African student) in Nanoscience got trained in this research area, two of them obtained PhD in Nanoscience. In addition, through collaboration with University of Akron, one more graduate student and two undergraduates got involved in this project, specifically, on the behavior studies of protein delivery in nanoscale. The new knowledge of the nanoplasmonics and nanotechnology was integrated into JSNN interdisciplinary curriculum as new course modules, specifically in 3-hour credit lecture courses, NAN-630 Advances in Nanobiosensors and NAN-724 Nanoscale Reactions, lab rotation course, NAN-611 Biosensors and Bioelectronics, NAN 740 Nonlinear Waves in Biological Media. Moreover, we actively participated the Gateway Science Festival (NC state wide) every year in April to showcase the local community and K-12 students through models, modules and video demonstration of the nanostructure photonics. In addition, our research has been exposed in public media such as the UNCG Research Magazine, The Triad Business Journal, Fox 8 News Interview, and won a few recognitions and awards, such as NSF I-Corps Spiritual award, Nano.gov annual video contest for Nanotechnology, the 1st place for the national NNCI and Nano.gov contest for their nanotech initiative contest, the world-wide Jove “film your research” contest, UNCG Research and Creativity Expo, and so on.
